title: Lesson 19: Working Scientifically
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding scientific investigation design including hypothesis formation, variables, risk assessment, and data processing in cell biology experiments.
learningIntentions: Students can design an investigation to test a hypothesis about cell biology (e.g., effect of temperature on membrane permeability, or factors affecting mitotic index).
Students can identify variables (independent, dependent, controlled) and risks in cell-based experiments.
Students can process and analyse data from cell biology experiments (calculations, graphs).

successCriteria: I can write a testable hypothesis for a cell biology investigation.
I can identify appropriate safety measures when handling cells or microscopes.
I can calculate a mitotic index from provided data.

engagementHook.title: The Experiment
engagementHook.content: 'You have the knowledge. Now design the test. Does hot water destroy cell membranes? Do plant cells grow better with more light? How would you prove it? Today you become the researcher, designing the investigation that could answer these questions safely and validly.'

keyConcepts.definition: Testable, falsifiable prediction (If X, then Y because Z).
Independent (what you change), Dependent (what you measure), Controlled (kept constant).
Biological hazards (cell lines, bacteria), Chemical hazards (stains, acids), Physical hazards (microscopes, hot water baths).
Mitotic index = (cells in mitosis / total cells) × 100%; growth curves (lag, log, stationary—link Lesson 15); unit conversions (Lesson 3).
Use of human/animal cells (informed consent, animal welfare), use of pathogens (safety).

misconceptions.misconception: You can test multiple variables at once
misconceptions.correction: Change only one independent variable to ensure valid cause-effect.
Both qualitative (descriptions) and quantitative (numbers) are valid data types.

misconceptions.misconception: A negative result means the experiment failed
misconceptions.correction: Negative results are still valid findings; hypothesis may be rejected.

contentSections.title: Designing a Valid Experiment
contentSections.problem: Test the effect of temperature on beetroot cell membrane permeability.
steps: Hypothesis: 'As temperature increases above 40°C, membrane permeability increases, causing more pigment leakage (measurable as increased absorbance).'
Dependent Variable: Absorbance of pigment in solution
Controlled Variables: Beetroot size, time, volume of water
Safety: Hot water burns—use water baths not Bunsen burners; beetroot stains—wear lab coat

contentSections.title: Calculating Mitotic Index
contentSections.content: Formula: (Cells in mitosis / Total cells) × 100. Example calculation from onion root tip data (link Lesson 12). High mitotic index = rapid growth (cancer tissue or growing root tip).
contentSections.example: Comparing cancerous vs normal tissue—cancer has higher mitotic index.

activities.title: Design a Caffeine Experiment
activities.description: Complete the experimental design components for testing caffeine's effect on mitosis.
activities.text:
You want to test if caffeine affects the rate of mitosis in onion root tips.

Hypothesis: [[If]] caffeine is added to onion root tips, [[then]] the mitotic index will increase [[because]] caffeine stimulates cell division.

Independent Variable: [[Caffeine concentration]]

Dependent Variable: [[Mitotic index]] (or number of cells in mitosis)

Two Controls: [[Temperature]], [[Onion type]] (or time/light)

Safety Consideration: [[Chemical handling]] (wear gloves/avoid ingestion)

multipleChoice.question: In an experiment testing the effect of pH on cell survival, the dependent variable is:
multipleChoice.rationale: Variable identification. Dependent variable is what you measure (outcome).

multipleChoice.question: The mitotic index is calculated by:
options: Dividing total cells by cells in mitosis
Dividing cells in mitosis by total cells and multiplying by 100
Measuring the size of the cells
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Dividing cells in mitosis by total cells and multiplying by 100

multipleChoice.question: When designing an experiment to test temperature effects on cells, which factor must be kept constant?
multipleChoice.rationale: Controlled variable concept. Factors other than the IV must remain constant.

shortAnswer.question: Identify the independent variable, dependent variable, and one controlled variable in an experiment to investigate the effect of salt concentration on osmosis in red blood cells. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Independent variable = concentration of salt solution (or salinity)
1 mark: Dependent variable = Volume of cells/degree of swelling or shrinking/cell appearance (or haemolysis rate)
1 mark: Controlled variable = Temperature/volume of solution/type of blood cells/time of exposure
shortAnswer.commonError: Confusing independent and dependent; stating 'osmosis' as the dependent variable (this is the process, not the measurement).

shortAnswer.question: Calculate the mitotic index for a tissue sample containing 500 cells, of which 25 are observed to be in various stages of mitosis. Show your working. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Correct method shown (25/500 × 100) or equivalent
shortAnswer.commonError: Giving answer as 0.05 without multiplying by 100 for percentage.

definitions: Independent variable: What you change; Dependent: What you measure; Controlled: What you keep constant.
Mitotic index = (Cells in mitosis / Total cells) × 100%.
Cell biology experiments require safety: biological hazards, chemical stains, hot equipment.
Valid experiments change only one variable at a time.
keyPoints: Hypothesis must be testable and falsifiable
Calculate mitotic index as a percentage

shortAnswer: In an experiment investigating the effect of salt concentration on osmosis in red blood cells: The independent variable is the concentration of the salt solution (this is what the researcher deliberately changes). The dependent variable is the volume of the cells or the degree of swelling or shrinking observed (this is what is measured as the outcome). A controlled variable would be the temperature of the solutions, the volume of solution used, the type of blood cells, or the time of exposure (any of these must be kept constant to ensure a fair test).
Mitotic index = (Cells in mitosis / Total cells) × 100 = (25 / 500) × 100 = 5%
